member.name: T:Iot.Device.Ads1115.MeasuringRange
member.summary: Configure the Programmable Gain Amplifier, i.e. Measuring Range Note that the maximum input value on any input pin is VDD+0.3V and the maximum value that can be measured is VDD. So if the supply voltage is 3.3V, using FS6144 may not be useful, because it just reduces the accuracy to 14 bit (excluding the sign bit).

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.InputMultiplexer
member.summary: ADS1115 Input Multiplexer. This selects the channel(s) for the next read operation, . Setting this property will wait until a value is available from the newly selected input channel.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.MeasuringRange
member.summary: ADS1115 Programmable Gain Amplifier This sets the maximum value that can be measured. Regardless of this setting, the input value on any pin must not exceed VDD + 0.3V, so high ranges are only usable with a VDD of more than 5V. Setting this property will wait until a new value is available.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.DataRate
member.summary: ADS1115 Data Rate. The number of conversions per second that will take place. One conversion will take "1/rate" seconds to become ready. If in power-down mode, only one conversion will happen automatically, then another request is required. Setting this property will wait until a new value is available.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.DeviceMode
member.summary: ADS1115 operation mode. When set to the chip continously measures the input and the values can be read directly. If set to the chip enters idle mode after each conversion and a new value will be requested each time a read request is performed. This is the recommended setting when frequently swapping between input channels, because a change of the channel requires a new conversion anyway.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.ComparatorMode
member.summary: Comparator mode. Only relevant if the comparator trigger event is set up and is changed by .

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.ComparatorPolarity
member.summary: Comparator polarity. Indicates whether the rising or the falling edge of the ALRT/RDY Pin is relevant. Default: Low (falling edge)

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.ComparatorLatching
member.summary: Comparator latching mode. If enabled, the ALRT/RDY Pin will be kept signaled until the conversion value is read. Only relevant when the comparator is enabled.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.ComparatorQueue
member.summary: Minimum number of samples exceeding the lower/upper threshold before the ALRT pin is asserted. This can only be set with .

member.name: E:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.AlertReadyAsserted
member.summary: This event fires when a new value is available (in conversion ready mode) or the comparator threshold is exceeded. Requires setup through or .

member.summary: Enable conversion ready event. The event fires each time a new value is available after this method is called.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.EnableComparator(UnitsNet.ElectricPotential,UnitsNet.ElectricPotential,Iot.Device.Ads1115.ComparatorMode,Iot.Device.Ads1115.ComparatorQueue)
member.summary: Enable comparator callback mode. In traditional comparator mode, the callback is triggered each time the measured value exceeds the given upper value (for the given queueLength number of samples). It deasserts when the lower value is reached. In window comparator mode, the callback is triggered each time the measured value exceeds the given upper value or gets less than the given lower value.
member.param: Lower value for the comparator
Upper value for the comparator
Traditional or Window comparator mode
Minimum number of samples that must exceed the threshold to trigger the event
member.exception: The GPIO Controller for the interrupt handler has not been set up

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.EnableComparator(System.Int16,System.Int16,Iot.Device.Ads1115.ComparatorMode,Iot.Device.Ads1115.ComparatorQueue)
member.summary: Enable comparator callback mode. In traditional comparator mode, the callback is triggered each time the measured value exceeds the given upper value (for the given queueLength number of samples). It deasserts when the lower value is reached. In window comparator mode, the callback is triggered each time the measured value exceeds the given upper value or gets less than the given lower value.
member.param: Lower value for the comparator
Upper value for the comparator
Traditional or Window comparator mode
Minimum number of samples that must exceed the threshold to trigger the event
member.exception: The GPIO Controller for the interrupt handler has not been set up

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ads1115.Ads1115.WaitWhileBusy
member.summary: Wait until the current conversion finishes. This method must only be called in powerdown mode, otherwise it would timeout, since the busy bit never changes. Due to that, we always write the configuration first in power down mode and then enable the continuous bit.
member.exception: A timeout occurred waiting for the ADC to finish the conversion

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Amg88xx.Amg88xx.HasTemperatureOverflow
member.summary: Gets whether any pixel measured a temperature higher than the normal operation range. The event of an overflow does not prevent from continuing reading the sensor. The overflow indication will last even if all pixels are returned to readings within normal range. The indicator is reset using .

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Amg88xx.Amg88xx.HasThermistorOverflow
member.summary: Gets the thermistor overflow flag from the status register. The overflow indication will last even if the thermistor temperature returned to normal range. The event of an overflow does not prevent from continuing reading the sensor. The indicator is reset using . Note: the bit is only menthioned in early versions of the reference specification. It is not clear whether this is a specification error or a change in a newer revision of the sensor.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Amg88xx.Amg88xx.Reset
member.summary: Performs an reset of the sensor. The flags and all configuration registers are reset to default values.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Amg88xx.Amg88xx.ResetAllFlags
member.summary: Performs a reset of all flags (status register, interrupt flag and interrupt table). This method is useful, if using the interrupt mechanism for pixel temperatures. If an upper and lower level has been set along with a hysteresis this reset can clear the interrupt state of all pixels which are within the range between upper and lower level, but still above/below the hystersis level. If this applies to ALL pixels the interrupt flag gets cleared as well. Refer to the binding documentation for more details on interrupt level, hysteresis and flagging.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Arduino.ArduinoBoard
member.summary: Implements an interface to an arduino board which is running Firmata. See documentation on how to prepare your arduino board to work with this. Note that the program will run on the PC, so you cannot disconnect the Arduino while this driver is connected.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.ArduinoBoard.#ctor(System.IO.Stream,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an instance of an Ardino board connection using the given stream (typically from a serial port)
member.remarks: The device is initialized when the first command is sent. The constructor always succeeds.
member.param: A stream to an Arduino/Firmata device
True to indicate that the stream supports hardware flow control (can be a serial port with RTS/CTS handshake or a network stream where the protocol already supports flow control)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.ArduinoBoard.#ctor(System.IO.Stream)
member.summary: Creates an instance of an Ardino board connection using the given stream (typically from a serial port)
member.remarks: The device is initialized when the first command is sent. The constructor always succeeds.
member.param: A stream to an Arduino/Firmata device

members.member:
Creates an instance of the Arduino board connection connected to a serial port
The device is initialized when the first command is sent. The constructor always succeeds. Port name. On Windows, this is usually "COM3" or "COM4" for an Arduino attached via USB. On Linux, possible values include "/dev/ttyAMA0", "/dev/serial0", "/dev/ttyUSB1", etc. Baudrate to use. It is recommended to use at least 115200 Baud.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Arduino.ArduinoBoard.StreamUsesHardwareFlowControl
member.summary: Set this to true if the underlying stream uses some kind of hardware or low-level flow control (RTS/CTS for a serial port, or a TCP socket). Setting this to true may improve performance on bulk transfers (such as large SPI blocks) but can result in buffer overflows if flow control is not working. Default: false

member.summary: Searches the given list of com ports for a firmata device.
member.remarks: Scanning ports and testing for devices may affect unrelated devices. It is advisable to exclude ports known to contain other hardware from this scan. A board won't be found if its port is already open (by the same or a different process).
member.param: List of com ports. Can be used with .
List of baud rates to test. .
[Out] Returns the board reference. It is already initialized.
member.returns: True on success, false if no board was found

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.ExtendedCommandHandler.OnSysexData(Iot.Device.Arduino.ReplyType,System.Byte[])
member.summary: This is called when a sysex command is received from the board. This can include the reply to a command sent by a before, in which case the reply should be ignored, as it is returned as result of the call itself. Therefore it is advised to use this function only to listen for data sent by the device automatically (e.g event messages or recurring status reports)
member.param: Type of data received from the hardware. This should normally be , unless the hardware sends unencoded Ascii messages
The binary representation of the received data
member.remarks: The implementation needs to check the type and source of the data. The messages are not filtered by requester!

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.ExtendedCommandHandler.IsMatchingAck(Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataCommandSequence,System.Byte[])
member.summary: This method is called to check whether the reply is a valid ACK/NOACK for the given command sequence. Can be used to avoid accepting something as command reply that is completely unrelated (such as an asynchronous callback). In different words, this should return false if the given reply is not something that is an answer to a synchronous command.
member.param: The sequence that was sent
The reply
member.returns: True if this reply matches the sequence. True is the default, for backwards compatibility

member.summary: Callback function that returns whether the given reply indicates an error

The reply. is already tested to be true for this reply
member.returns: A command error code, in case this reply indicates a no-acknowledge

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice._dataReceived
member.summary: Event used when waiting for answers (i.e. after requesting firmware version)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.SendCommand(Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataCommandSequence)
member.summary: Send a command that does not generate a reply. This method must only be used for commands that do not generate a reply. It must not be used if only the caller is not interested in the answer.
member.param: The command sequence to send

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.SendCommandAndWait(Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataCommandSequence,System.TimeSpan,System.Func{Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataCommandSequence,System.Byte[],System.Boolean},Iot.Device.Arduino.CommandError@)
member.summary: Send a command and wait for a reply
member.param: The command sequence, typically starting with and ending with
A non-default timeout
A callback function that should return true if the given reply is the one this command should wait for. The default is true, because asynchronous replies are rather the exception than the rule
An error code in case of failure
member.returns: The raw sequence of sysex reply bytes. The reply does not include the START_SYSEX byte, but it does include the terminating END_SYSEX byte. The first byte is the command number of the corresponding request

member.summary: Send a command and wait for a reply
member.param: The command sequences to send, typically starting with and ending with
A non-default timeout
A callback function that should return true if the given reply is the one this command should wait for. The default is true, because asynchronous replies are rather the exception than the rule
A callback that determines a possible error in the reply message
An error code in case of failure
member.returns: The raw sequence of sysex reply bytes. The reply does not include the START_SYSEX byte, but it does include the terminating END_SYSEX byte. The first byte is the command number of the corresponding request

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.ReplaceFirst(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Replaces the first occurrence of search in input with replace.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.PrintfFromByteStream(System.String,System.Span{System.Byte}@,System.Int32)
member.summary: Simulates a printf C statement. Note that the word size on the arduino is 16 bits, so any argument not specifying an l prefix is considered to be 16 bits only.
member.param: Format string (with %d, %x, etc)
Total bytes received
Start of arguments (first byte of formatting parameters)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.EnableDigitalReporting
member.summary: Enables digital pin reporting for all ports (one port has 8 pins)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.EnableAnalogReporting(System.Int32)
member.summary: This takes the pin number in Arduino's own Analog numbering scheme. So A0 shall be specifed as 0

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FirmataDevice.ReassembleByteString(System.Collections.Generic.IList{System.Byte},System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Span{System.Byte})
member.summary: Firmata uses 2 bytes to encode 8-bit data, because byte values with the top bit set are reserved for commands. This decodes such data chunks.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencyMode
member.summary: Defines on which events the frequency counter should increase.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencyMode.Low
member.summary: Trigger when the value is low. Use with care: This triggers an internal interrupt AS LONG AS the value on the pin is low, which may completely lock up the board.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencyMode.High
member.summary: Trigger when the value is high. This mode is only supported on some boards.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencyMode.Change
member.summary: Trigger on both edges. Note that this will typically result in a frequency reported twice as high as it actually is.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencySensor
member.summary: The frequency extension allows detecting the frequency of a signal at a given pin. This extension is supported on gpio pins that support interrupts.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencySensor.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new instance of this class. This supports pins that have the "Frequency" mode enabled.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencySensor.EnableFrequencyReporting(System.Int32,Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencyMode,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enable frequency reporting on the given pin.
member.param: The pin number
The mode on which to increase the tick count. Typically rising or falling edge.
How often the value should update, in milliseconds. Must be positive and smaller than 2^14

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencySensor.GetMeasuredFrequency
member.summary: Returns the last measured frequency. Returns 0 if no frequency measurement is active.
member.returns: The frequency measured during the last interval

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Arduino.FrequencySensor.DisableFrequencyReporting(System.Int32)
member.summary: Disables automatic updating of the frequency counter for the given pin
member.param: The pin to use

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Arduino.ReplyType
member.summary: Type of a message returned from the board

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Arduino.ReplyType.SysexCommand
member.summary: A sysex message was received. This is the default. The message buffer contains the binary reply data without the sysex byte.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Arduino.ReplyType.AsciiData
member.summary: A text message was received. This may happen if a special script runs on the firmata device that prints raw ASCII characters to the console. One occasion where this also happens is if an ESP32 is printing a crash dump. The payload contains the raw message in unicode bytes.

member.summary: The pin can be used for SPI transfer (Clock, MOSI, MISO and default CS pin) For most Arduinos, MOSI=11, MISO=12 and Clock = 13. The default CS pin is 10.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.FilteringMode.Bme680FilteringMode
member.summary: IIR filter coefficient. The higher the coefficient, the slower the sensors responds to external inputs.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.FilteringMode.Bmx280FilteringMode
member.summary: Bmx280 devices feature an internal IIR filter.
member.remarks:
This filter effectively reduces the bandwidth of the temperature and pressure output signals and increases the resolution of the pressure and temperature output data to 20 bits.
The higher the coefficient, the slower the sensors responds to external inputs.
See the data sheet with recommended settings for different scenarios.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.PowerMode.Bme680PowerMode
member.remarks: Section 3.1 in the datasheet.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.PowerMode.Bme680PowerMode.Sleep
member.remarks: Minimal power consumption.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.PowerMode.Bme680PowerMode.Forced
member.remarks: Sensor automatically returns to sleep mode afterwards. Gas sensor heater only operates during gas measurement.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.PowerMode.Bmx280PowerMode.Sleep
member.summary: No operations, all registers accessible, lowest power mode, selected after startup.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.PowerMode.Bmx280PowerMode.Forced
member.summary: Perform one measurement, store results, and return to sleep mode.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Bmxx80.PowerMode.Bmx280PowerMode.Normal
member.summary: Perpetual cycling of measurements and inactive periods. This interval is determined by the combination of IIR filter and standby time options.

member.summary: The kernel controls the trigger of the LED.
member.remarks: The kernel provides some triggers which let the kernel control the LED. For example, the red light of Raspberry Pi, whose trigger is "default-on", which makes it keep lighting up. If you want to operate the LED, you need to remove the trigger, which is to set its trigger to none. Use to get all triggers.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Board.Board
member.summary: Base class for all board abstractions. A "board" is a piece of hardware that offers low-level interfaces to other devices. Typically, it has GPIO pins and one or multiple SPI or I2C busses. There should be exactly one instance of a board class per hardware component in an application, but it is possible to work with multiple boards at once (i.e. when having a GPIO expander connected to the Raspberry Pi)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Board.Board.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a board instance with the default numbering scheme.
member.remarks: The constructor will never throw an exception. Call any other method to initialize the hardware and check whether an instance can actually run on the current hardware.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Board.Board.GetBestDriverForBoardOnLinux
member.summary: Attempt to get the best applicable driver for the board the program is executing on.
member.returns: A driver that works with the board the program is executing on.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Board.Board.GetBestDriverForBoardOnWindows
member.summary: Attempt to get the best applicable driver for the board the program is executing on.
member.returns: A driver that works with the board the program is executing on.
member.remarks: This really feels like it needs a driver-based pattern, where each driver exposes a static method: public static bool IsSpecificToCurrentEnvironment { get; } The GpioController could use reflection to find all GpioDriver-derived classes and call this static method to determine if the driver considers itself to be the best match for the environment. (Implementation copied from , where it is private)

The highest address to scan. Default 0x77

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Board.KeyboardGpioDriver
member.summary: A GPIO Driver for testing on Windows This driver uses the keyboard for simulating GPIO pins. Pins 0-2 are output only and represent the keyboard LEDs (Caps lock, Scroll Lock and Num Lock). Setting a value to any of these pins toggles the LEDs on the keyboard (if they're physically present). Pins above 8 are input only and represent the keyboard keys. To get the pin number, cast the corresponding to int, e.g. int pinNumber = (int)ConsoleKey.A

member.name: M:Iot.Device.BrickPi3.Brick.GetSensor(System.Byte)
member.summary: Get the sensor data from a specific port The following sensor types each return a single value: NONE----------------------- 0 TOUCH---------------------- 0 or 1(released or pressed) NXT_TOUCH------------------ 0 or 1(released or pressed) EV3_TOUCH------------------ 0 or 1(released or pressed) NXT_ULTRASONIC------------- distance in CM NXT_LIGHT_ON--------------- reflected light NXT_LIGHT_OFF-------------- ambient light NXT_COLOR_RED-------------- red reflected light NXT_COLOR_GREEN------------ green reflected light NXT_COLOR_BLUE------------- blue reflected light NXT_COLOR_OFF-------------- ambient light EV3_GYRO_ABS--------------- absolute rotation position in degrees EV3_GYRO_DPS--------------- rotation rate in degrees per second EV3_COLOR_REFLECTED-------- red reflected light EV3_COLOR_AMBIENT---------- ambient light EV3_COLOR_COLOR------------ detected color EV3_ULTRASONIC_CM---------- distance in CM EV3_ULTRASONIC_INCHES------ distance in inches EV3_ULTRASONIC_LISTEN------ 0 or 1(no other ultrasonic sensors or another ultrasonic sensor detected) EV3_INFRARED_PROXIMITY----- distance 0 - 100 % The following sensor types each return a list of values CUSTOM--------------------- Pin 1 ADC(5v scale from 0 to 4095), Pin 6 ADC(3.3v scale from 0 to 4095), Pin 5 digital, Pin 6 digital I2C------------------------ the I2C bytes read NXT_COLOR_FULL------------- detected color, red light reflected, green light reflected, blue light reflected, ambient light EV3_GYRO_ABS_DPS----------- absolute rotation position in degrees, rotation rate in degrees per second EV3_COLOR_RAW_REFLECTED---- red reflected light, unknown value(maybe a raw ambient value ?) EV3_COLOR_COLOR_COMPONENTS- red reflected light, green reflected light, blue reflected light, unknown value(maybe a raw value ?) EV3_INFRARED_SEEK---------- a list for each of the four channels.For each channel heading(-25 to 25), distance(-128 or 0 to 100) EV3_INFRARED_REMOTE-------- a list for each of the four channels.For each channel red up, red down, blue up, blue down, boadcast
member.param: The sensor port(one at a time). Port 1, 2, 3, or 4
member.returns: Returns the value(s) for the specified sensor.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.BrickPi3.Brick.SetSensorType(System.Byte,Iot.Device.BrickPi3.Models.SensorType,System.Int32[])
member.param: The sensor port(s). Port 1, 2, 3, and/or 4
The sensor type

param is used only for some sensors and can be ignore for the others param is used for the following sensor types: CUSTOM-- a 16 - bit integer used to configure the hardware. I2C-- a list of settings: param[0]-- Settings / flags param[1] -- target Speed in microseconds(0-255). Realistically the speed will vary. if SENSOR_I2C_SETTINGS_SAME flag set in I2C Settings: param[2] -- Delay in microseconds between transactions. param[3] -- Address param[4] -- List of bytes to write param[5] -- Number of bytes to read

member.name: M:Iot.Device.BrickPi3.Brick.SetMotorPositionKP(System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Set the motor target position KP constant If you set KP higher, the motor will be more responsive to errors in position, at the cost of perhaps overshooting and oscillating. KP slows down the motor as it approaches the target, and helps to prevent overshoot. In general, if you increase KP, you should also increase KD to keep the motor from overshooting and oscillating.
member.param: The Motor port(s). PortA, PortB, PortC, and/or PortD.
The KP constant (default 25)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.BrickPi3.Brick.SetMotorPositionKD(System.Byte,System.Byte)
member.summary: Set the motor target position KD constant If you set KP higher, the motor will be more responsive to errors in position, at the cost of perhaps overshooting and oscillating. KD slows down the motor as it approaches the target, and helps to prevent overshoot. In general, if you increase kp, you should also increase KD to keep the motor from overshooting and oscillating.
member.param: The Motor port(s). PortA, PortB, PortC, and/or PortD.
The KD constant (default 70)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.BrickPi3.Brick.SetMotorDps(System.Byte,System.Int32)
member.summary: Set the motor target speed in degrees per second
member.param: The Motor port(s). PortA, PortB, PortC, and/or PortD.
The target speed in degrees per second

member.param: The Motor port(s). PortA, PortB, PortC, and/or PortD.
The power limit in percent (0 to 100), with 0 being no limit (100)
The speed limit in degrees per second, with 0 being no limit

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Card.CardTransceiver
member.summary: Abstract class implementing a specific Write and Read function This class allow to transceive information with the card This class has to be implemented in all RFID/NFC/Card readers So Mifare cards can be used the same way independent of any reader

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Card.CardTransceiver.Transceive(System.Byte,System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte},System.Span{System.Byte})
member.summary: This function has to be implemented by all NFC/RFID/Card readers. This function is used in exchange of data with the reader and the cards.
member.param: Some readers have a notion of target number for the cards as they can read multiple ones
A standardized raw buffer with the command at the position 0 in the array
If any data are read from the card, they will be put into this array
member.returns: -1 in case of error, otherwise the number of bytes read and copied into the array

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Card.CardTransceiver.ReselectTarget(System.Byte)
member.summary: Once you have an authentication operation failing with Mifare cards or a read/write, the card stop. TYhe only way to have it back is to send the unselect and anti collision. This function provides this feature
member.param: The target number to reselect

member.summary: Ultra-Low Power Digital Gas Sensor for Monitoring Indoor Air Quality Documentation can be found here: https://www.sciosense.com/products/environmental-sensors/ccs811-gas-sensor-solution/

member.summary: The second default I2C address when the Address pin is put to high

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Ccs811.Ccs811Sensor.I2cTypicalFrequency
member.summary: The typical operating speed for the bus Note that minimum is 10 KHz and the maximum is 400 KHz The device can operate in Stretching mode is the transfer is too fast. This stretching may not be well supported in all the hardware, in case of issue, it is recommended to lower the operating frequency

The measurement

member.param: A valid I2C device
An optional controller, either the default one will be used, either none will be created if any pin is used
An awake pin, it is optional, this pin can be set to the ground if the sensor is always on
An interruption pin when a measurement is ready, best use when you specify a threshold
An optional hard reset pin
Should the GPIO controller be disposed at the end

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ccs811.Ccs811Sensor.TryReadGasData(UnitsNet.VolumeConcentration@,UnitsNet.VolumeConcentration@,UnitsNet.ElectricCurrent@,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Read the equivalent CO2 in ppm and equivalent Total Volatile Compound in ppb
member.param: The equivalent CO2 (eCO2) output range for CCS811 is from 400ppm up to 29206ppm.
The equivalent Total Volatile Organic Compound (eTVOC) output range for CCS811 is from 0ppb up to 32768ppb
Raw data containing the value of the current through the sensor(0μA to 63μA)
Raw data containing the readings of the voltage across the sensor with the selected current(1023 = 1.65V) where 1023 is the maximum value

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ccs811.Ccs811Sensor.TryReadGasData(UnitsNet.VolumeConcentration@,UnitsNet.VolumeConcentration@)
member.summary: Read the equivalent CO2 in ppm and equivalent Total Volatile Compound in ppb
member.param: The equivalent CO2 (eCO2) output range for CCS811 is from 400ppm up to 29206ppm.
The equivalent Total Volatile Organic Compound (eTVOC) output range for CCS811 is from 0ppb up to 32768ppb

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Ccs811.Ccs811Sensor.BaselineAlgorithmCalculation
member.summary: Get or set the encoded version of the current baseline used in Algorithm Calculations
member.remarks: A previously stored value may be written back to this two byte register and the Algorithms will use the new value in its calculations(until it adjusts it as part of its internal Automatic Baseline Correction). Please refer to documentation to understand when to restore a previous baseline: https://www.sciosense.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Application-Note-Baseline-Save-and-Restore-on-CCS811.pdf

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ccs811.Ccs811Sensor.SetEnvironmentData(UnitsNet.Temperature,UnitsNet.RelativeHumidity)
member.summary: Set the environmental data, this is impacting the equivalent calculation of the gas.
member.param: The temperature
The relative humidity, best to use Percent from 0 to 100

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Ccs811.Ccs811Sensor.SetThreshold(UnitsNet.VolumeConcentration,UnitsNet.VolumeConcentration)
member.summary: Set the threshold for the equivalent CO2. The pinInterrupt should be existing so interruptions are activated. If not, then the function will return false
member.param: The low value for the threshold
The high value for the threshold
member.remarks: Difference between the low and high value should be more than 50. This is called the hysteresis value.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.DisplayFunction.ExtendedInstructionSet
member.summary: When set, commands (other than ) are from the extended (NXP/Philips, Sitronix) instruction set. For Sitronix (ST7036) this is extended intstruction set 1.
member.remarks: The "H" option from the NXP datasheet. The "IS1" option from Sitronix. Not all driver ICs support this.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.DisplayFunction.Font5x10
member.summary: If set font is 5x10, otherwise font is 5x8.
member.remarks:
The "F" option from the HD44780 datasheet.
The displays that supported 5x10 are extremely rare.
On NXP/Philips chips this is the "M" option that controls the number of display lines. When set the driver is set to 2 line x 16 characters. Otherwise the driver is set to 1 line by 32 characters.
For Sitronix, this is referred to as "DH" and sets double height mode.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.DisplayFunction.TwoLine
member.summary: If set display is two line, otherwise display is one line.
member.remarks:
The "N" option from the datasheet.
When set to one line, shifting the display right pulls address 0x4F to the 1st display position. When set to two lines, shifting right pulls 0x27 for the first line and 0x67 for the second.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.DisplayFunction.EightBit
member.summary: If set display uses all eight data pins, otherwise display uses four data pins.
member.remarks: The "DL" option from the datasheet.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.DisplayFunction.Command
member.summary: The flag for setting display function- must be set.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.Hd44780
member.summary: Supports LCD character displays compatible with the HD44780 LCD controller/driver. Also supports serial interface adapters such as the MCP23008.
member.remarks:
The Hitatchi HD44780 was released in 1987 and set the standard for LCD controllers. Hitatchi does not make this chipset anymore, but most character LCD drivers are intended to be fully compatible with this chipset. Some examples: Sunplus SPLC780D, Sitronix ST7066U, Samsung KS0066U, Aiptek AIP31066, and many more.
Some compatible chips extend the HD44780 with addtional pins and features. They are still fully compatible. The ST7036 is one example.
This implementation was drawn from numerous datasheets and libraries such as Adafruit_Python_CharLCD.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.Hd44780.CreateCustomCharacter(System.Int32,System.ReadOnlySpan{System.Byte})
member.summary: Fill one of the 8 CGRAM locations (character codes 0 - 7) with custom characters.
member.remarks:
The custom characters also occupy character codes 8 - 15.
You can find help designing characters at https://www.quinapalus.com/hd44780udg.html.
The datasheet description for custom characters is very difficult to follow. Here is a rehash of the technical details that is hopefully easier:
Only 6 bits of addresses are available for character ram. That makes for 64 bytes of available character data. 8 bytes of data are used for each character, which is where the 8 total custom characters comes from (64/8).
Each byte corresponds to a character line. Characters are only 5 bits wide so only bits 0-4 are used for display. Whatever is in bits 5-7 is just ignored. Store bits there if it makes you happy, but it won't impact the display. '1' is on, '0' is off.
In the built-in characters the 8th byte is usually empty as this is where the underline cursor will be if enabled. You can put data there if you like, which gives you the full 5x8 character. The underline cursor just turns on the entire bottom row.
5x10 mode is effectively useless as displays aren't available that utilize it. In 5x10 mode *16* bytes of data are used for each character. That leaves room for only *4* custom characters. The first character is addressable from code 0, 1, 8, and 9. The second is 2, 3, 10, 11 and so on...
In this mode *11* bytes of data are actually used for the character data, which effectively gives you a 5x11 character, although typically the last line is blank to leave room for the underline cursor. Why the modes are referred to as 5x8 and 5x10 as opposed to 5x7 and 5x10 or 5x8 and 5x11 is a mystery. In an early pre-release data book 5x7 and 5x10 is used (Advance Copy #AP4 from July 1985). Perhaps it was a marketing change?
As only 11 bytes are used in 5x10 mode, but 16 bytes are reserved, the last 5 bytes are useless. The datasheet helpfully suggests that you can store your own data there. The same would be true for bits 5-7 of lines that matter for both 5x8 and 5x10.
member.param: Should be between 0 and 7
Provide an array of 8 bytes containing the pattern

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.Hd44780.CreateCustomCharacter(System.Int32,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Fill one of the 8 CGRAM locations (character codes 0 - 7) with custom characters. See for details.
member.param: Should be between 0 and 7
Provide an array of 8 bytes containing the pattern

member.summary: Loads the specified encoding. This behaves as when the argument is of the dynamic type , otherwise like an encding with no special characters.
member.param: The encoding to load.
member.returns: See true if the encoding was correctly loaded.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdConsole.LoadEncoding(Iot.Device.Graphics.LcdCharacterEncoding)
member.summary: Loads the specified character encoding. This loads any custom characters from the encoding to the display.
member.param: The encoding to load.
member.returns: True if the character encoding was successfully loaded, false if there are not enough custom slots for all the required custom characters. This may also return false if the encoding factory returned incomplete results, such as a missing custom character for a special diacritic.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdConsole.ResetEncoding
member.summary: Resets the character encoding to hardware defaults (using simply the lower byte of a char).

member.summary: The initialization sequence and some other complex commands should be sent with delays, or the display may behave unexpectedly. It may show random, blinking characters or display text very faintly only.
member.param: The command to send

member.name: P:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.EightBitMode
member.summary: True if device uses 8-bits for communication, false if device uses 4-bits

member.name: P:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.WaitMultiplier
member.summary: The command wait time multiplier for the LCD.
member.remarks:
In order to handle controllers that might be running at a much slower clock we're exposing a multiplier for any "hard coded" waits. This can also be used to reduce the wait time when the clock runs faster or other overhead (time spent in other code) allows for more aggressive timing.
There is a busy signal that can be checked that could make this moot, but currently we are unable to check the signal fast enough to make gains (or even equal) going off hard timings. The busy signal also requires having a r/w pin attached.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.WaitForNotBusy(System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait for the device to not be busy.
member.param: Time to wait if checking busy state isn't possible/practical.

member.summary: Register select pin. Low is for writing to the instruction register and reading the address counter. High is for reading and writing to the data register.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.Gpio._rwPin
member.summary: Read/write pin. Low for write, high for read.

member.summary: Enable pin. Pulse high to process a read/write.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.I2c
member.summary: Built-in I2c access to the Hd44780 compatible controller. The Philips/NXP LCD driver ICs (such as the PCF2119x) are examples of this support.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.I2c.ControlByteFlags.ControlByteFollows
member.summary: When set, another control byte will follow the next data/command byte. Otherwise the last control byte will be used.
member.remarks: This is only relevant when sending multiple bytes of data to the register. When a new I2c transmission is made, the first byte is always assumed to be a control byte. This flag is needed if you want to flip the "RS" bit in a stream of bytes.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.I2c.ControlByteFlags.RegisterSelect
member.summary: When set the data register will be selected (i.e. equivalent to RS pin being high). Otherwise the instruction/command register will be updated.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.I2c4Bit
member.summary: Built-in I2c access to the Hd44780 compatible controller. The Philips/NXP LCD driver ICs (such as the PCF2119x) are examples of this support. This driver uses 4-Bit access (each character/command is split into 2x4 bits for transmission)

member.name: P:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.I2c4Bit.BacklightOn
member.summary: This Display supports enabling/disabling the backlight. The text on the display is not affected by disabling the backlight - it is just very hard to read.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdInterface.ShiftRegisterLcdInterface
member.summary: This interface allows the control of a character lcd using a shift register. The shift register can be controlled using a minimum of three pins so using this method saves pins on the microcontroller compared to direct GPIO connection. This interface adds support for I/O expanders that allow connection to an HD44780 display through a shift register e.g. https://www.adafruit.com/product/292

member.summary: Displays a value and an unit in a big font on an LCD Display. Requires a display with at least 20x4 characters

User culture

member.summary: Initializes the display for use as a big-number display. Configures the display with some graphic blocks for the display of big numbers.
member.param: Name of the character Rom, required to properly print culture-specific characters in the small text display
Encoding factory or null

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdValueUnitDisplay.StopShowing
member.summary: Stop showing big characters. This method can be used to signal that the display will be used for different purposes. Before a Display method is used, needs to be called again. This clears the display.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdValueUnitDisplay.DisplayTime(System.DateTime,System.String)
member.param: Time to display

Time format specifier, default "t" (default short time format with hours and minutes and eventually AM/PM). Anything after the first space in the formatted string is printed as small text. This will for instance be AM/PM when the format specifier "T" is used, since only 6 chars (and two separators) fit on the display.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LcdValueUnitDisplay.DisplayValue(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Display the given value/unit pair. The value must be pre-formatted with the required number of digits, ie. "2.01". The value should only contain one of ".", ":" or ",", or the printed result may be unexpected.
member.param: Pre-formatted value to print
Unit or name of value. This is printed in normal small font on the bottom right corner of the display.

member.summary: Scrolls a text in big font trough the display
member.param: Text to display
Speed between scroll steps (one step being one display cell width)
Token for cancelling the operation

member.summary: Character code 7 is always used for the separation char, which is one of ":", "." or ",".

member.summary: The cursor will stay beyond the edge of the screen. Any further write attempts will not do anything until the cursor is moved or the display cleared. A newline will move to the next line, unless already on the last line of the display.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LineWrapMode.Wrap

member.name: F:Iot.Device.CharacterLcd.LineWrapMode.WordWrap
member.summary: Attempts to wrap at word borders when the text does not fit on the (remaining part of) the line.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Common.GeographicPosition
member.summary: Represents a position in WGS84 coordinates. This is the standard coordinate format for most GNSS receivers currently available. An instance with Latitude = Longitude = Height = 0 is considered invalid. A real GNSS receiver will never output this exact value and that position is far out in the ocean.
member.remarks: This object stores ellipsoidal height, depending on the GNSS receiver and the application, this needs to be transformed to geoidal height.

member.param: Input position 1
Input position 2
Great circle distance between the positions
Initial direction to travel, in degrees true
member.exception: Either or are null.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Common.WeatherHelper.GetRelativeHumidityFromActualAirTemperature(UnitsNet.Temperature,UnitsNet.RelativeHumidity,UnitsNet.Temperature)
member.summary: Calculates a corrected relative humidity. This is useful if you have a temperature/humidity sensor that is placed in a location where the temperature is different from the real ambient temperature (like it sits inside a hot case) and another temperature-only sensor that gives more reasonable ambient temperature readings. Do note that the relative humidity is dependent on the temperature, because it depends on how much water a volume of air can contain, which increases with temperature.
member.param: Temperature measured by the humidity sensor
Humidity measured
Temperature measured by better placed sensor
member.returns: A corrected humidity. The value will be lower than the input value if the better placed sensor is cooler than the "bad" sensor.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Common.WeatherHelper.CalculateBarometricPressure(UnitsNet.Pressure,UnitsNet.Temperature,UnitsNet.Length)
member.summary:
Calculates the barometric pressure from a raw reading, using the reduction formula from the german met service. This is a more complex variant of . It gives the value that a weather station gives for a particular area and is also used in meteorological charts.
You are at 650m over sea and measure a pressure of 948.7 hPa and a temperature of 24.0°C. The met service will show that you are within a high-pressure area of around 1020 hPa.
member.param: Measured pressure at the observation point
Measured temperature at the observation point

Height over sea level of the observation point (to be really precise, geopotential heights have to be used above ~750m). Do not use the height obtained by calling or any of its overloads, since that would use redundant data.
member.returns: The barometric pressure at the point of observation
member.remarks: From https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barometrische_Höhenformel#Anwendungen

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Common.WeatherHelper.CalculateBarometricPressure(UnitsNet.Pressure,UnitsNet.Temperature,UnitsNet.Pressure,UnitsNet.Length)
member.summary:
Calculates the barometric pressure from a raw reading, using the reduction formula from the german met service. This is a more complex variant of . It gives the value that a weather station gives for a particular area and is also used in meteorological charts.
You are at 650m over sea and measure a pressure of 948.7 hPa and a temperature of 24.0°C. The met service will show that you are within a high-pressure area of around 1020 hPa.
member.param: Measured pressure at the observation point
Measured temperature at the observation point
Vapor pressure, meteorologic definition
Height over sea level of the observation point (to be really precise, geopotential heights have to be used above ~750m)
member.returns: The barometric pressure at the point of observation
member.remarks: From https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barometrische_Höhenformel#Anwendungen

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Common.WeatherHelper.CalculateBarometricPressure(UnitsNet.Pressure,UnitsNet.Temperature,UnitsNet.Length,UnitsNet.RelativeHumidity)
member.summary: Calculates the barometric pressure from a raw reading, using the reduction formula from the german met service. This is a more complex variant of . It gives the value that a weather station gives for a particular area and is also used in meteorological charts. Use this method if you also have the relative humidity.
member.param: Measured pressure at the observation point
Measured temperature at the observation point
Height over sea level of the observation point (to be really precise, geopotential heights have to be used above ~750m)
Relative humidity at point of measurement
member.returns: The barometric pressure at the point of observation
member.remarks: From https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barometrische_Höhenformel#Anwendungen

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Graphics.LcdCharacterEncodingFactory.Create(System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.String,System.Char,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates the character mapping optimized for the given culture. Checks whether the characters required for a given culture are available in the installed character map and tries to add them as user-defined characters, if possible.
member.param: Culture for which support is required
ROM type of attached chip. Supported values: "A00", "A02", "SplC780"
Letter that is printed when an unknown character is encountered. This letter must be part of the default rom set
Maximum number of custom characters supported on the hardware. Should be 8 for Hd44780-controlled displays.
member.returns: The newly created encoding. Whether the encoding can be loaded to a certain display will be decided later.
member.exception: The character specified as unknownLetter must be part of the mapping.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Graphics.LcdCharacterEncodingFactory.AssignLettersForCurrentCulture(System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Char,System.Byte},System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.String,System.Collections.Generic.List{System.Byte[]},System.Int32)
member.summary: Tries to generate letters important in that culture but missing from the current rom set

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Graphics.LcdCharacterEncodingFactory.SpecialLettersForCulture(System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Char,System.Byte})
member.summary: Returns the set of special characters required for a given culture/language. This may include diacritics (ä, ö, ø), currency signs (€) or similar chars. If any of the returned characters are not found in the ROM map, is called to obtain the pixel representation of the given character. A maximum of 8 extra characters can be added to the ones in the ROM.
member.param: Culture to support

The character map, pre-loaded with the characters from the character ROM. This may be extended by explicitly adding direct mappings where an alternative is allowed (i.e. mapping capital diacritics to normal capital letters É -> E, when there's not enough room to put É into character RAM.
member.returns: A string with the set of special characters for a language, i.e. "äöüß€ÄÖÜ" for German

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Graphics.LcdCharacterEncodingFactory.CreateLetter(System.Char,System.String)
member.summary: Creates the given letter for the given ROM type. Overwrite this only if an alternate ROM is used.

member.summary: Creates the given letter from a pixel map for Rom Type A00 (7-pixel high letters, bottom row empty)

member.returns: An 8-Byte array of the pixel map for the created letter.
member.remarks: Currently requires the characters to be hardcoded here. Would be nice if we could generate the pixel maps from an existing font, such as Consolas

member.summary: Combines a set of bytes into a pixel map
member.example:
Use as follows to create letter 'ü':
CreateCustomCharacter( 0b_01010, 0b_00000, 0b_10001, 0b_10001, 0b_10001, 0b_10011, 0b_01101, 0b_00000)

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.ConnectTDItoTDOforLoopback
member.summary: 0x84, This will connect the TDI/DO output to the TDO/DI input for loopback testing.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.DisconnectTDItoTDOforLoopback
member.summary: 0x85, This will disconnect the TDI output from the TDO input for loopback testing.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.SetTCKSKDivisor
member.summary: Set TCK/SK Divisor (FT2232D) 0x86, 0xValueL, 0xValueH TCK/SK period = 12MHz / (( 1 +[(0xValueH * 256) OR 0xValueL] ) * 2)

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.SetClockDivisor
member.summary: 0x86, 0xValueL, 0xValueH, or example with the divide by 5 set as on: The TCK frequency can be worked out by the following algorithm : TCK period = 12MHz / (( 1 +[ (0xValueH * 256) OR 0xValueL] ) * 2) 0x0000 6 MHz 0xFFFF 91.553 Hz For example with the divide by 5 set as off: The TCK frequency can be worked out by the following algorithm : TCK period = 60MHz / (( 1 +[ (0xValueH * 256) OR 0xValueL] ) * 2) 0x0000 30 MHz 0xFFFF 457.763 Hz

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.CPUModeReadShortAddress
member.summary: 0x90, 0xAddrLow This will read 1 byte from the target device.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.CPUModeReadExtendedAddress
member.summary: 0x91, 0xAddrHigh 0xAddrLow This will read 1 byte from the target device.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.CPUModeWriteShortAddress
member.summary: 0x92, 0xAddrLow, 0xData This will write 1 byte from the target device.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.CPUModeWriteExtendedAddress
member.summary: 0x93, 0xAddrHigh, 0xAddrLow, 0xData This will write 1 byte from the target device.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.SendImmediate
member.summary: 0x87, This will make the chip flush its buffer back to the PC.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.WaitOnIOHigh
member.summary: 0x88, This will cause the MPSSE controller to wait until GPIOL1 (JTAG) or I/O1 (CPU) is high. Once it is detected as high, it will move on to process the next instruction. The only way out of this will be to disable the controller if the I/O line never goes high.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.WaitOnIOLow
member.summary: 0x89, This will cause the controller to wait until GPIOL1 (JTAG) or I/O1 (CPU) is low. Once it is detected as low, it will move on to process the next instruction. The only way out of this will be to disable the controller if the I/O line never goes low.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.DisableClockDivideBy5
member.summary: 0x8A This will turn off the divide by 5 from the 60 MHz clock.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.EnableClockDivideBy5
member.summary: 0x8B This will turn on the divide by 5 from the 60 MHz clock to give a 12MHz master clock for backward compatibility with FT2232D designs

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.Enable3PhaseDataClocking
member.summary: 0x8C This will give a 3 stage data shift for the purposes of supporting interfaces such as I2C which need the data to be valid on both edges of the clk. So it will appear as Data setup for ½ clock period -> pulse clock for ½ clock period -> Data hold for ½ clock period.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.Disable3PhaseDataClocking
member.summary: 0x8D This will give a 2 stage data shift which is the default state. So it will appear as Data setup for ½ clock period -> Pulse clock for ½ clock period

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.ClockForNx8BitsWithNoDataTransfer
member.summary: 0x8F LengthL, LengthH, A length of 0x0000 will do 8 clocks and a length of 0xFFFF will do 524288 clocks

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.TurnOnAdaptativeClocking
member.summary: 0x96, Adaptive clocking is required when using the JTAG interface on an ARM processor.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.ClockForNx8BitsWithNoDataTransferOrUntilGPIOL1IsHigh
member.summary: 0x9C LengthL, LengthH, A length of 0x0000 will do 8 clocks and a length of 0xFFFF will do 524288 clocks or until GPIOL1 is high.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.ClockForNx8BitsWithNoDataTransferOrUntilGPIOL1IsLow
member.summary: 0x9D LengthL, LengthH, A length of 0x0000 will do 8 clocks and a length of 0xFFFF will do 524288 clocks or until GPIOL1 is low.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.FtCommon.FtOpcode.SetIOOnlyDriveOn0AndTristateOn1
member.summary: 0x9E LowByteEnablesForOnlyDrive0 HighByteEnablesForOnlyDrive0 This will make the I/Os only drive when the data is ‘0’ and tristate on the data being ‘1’ when the appropriate bit is set. Use this op-code when configuring the MPSSE for I2C use.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.GoPiGo3.GoPiGo.SetMotorPositionKP(Iot.Device.GoPiGo3.Models.MotorPort,System.Byte)
member.summary: Set the motor target position KP constant If you set KP higher, the motor will be more responsive to errors in position, at the cost of perhaps overshooting and oscillating. KD slows down the motor as it approaches the target, and helps to prevent overshoot. In general, if you increase KP, you should also increase KD to keep the motor from overshooting and oscillating. See as well https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PID_controller
member.param: The Motor port to use, can be MotorLeft and/or MotorRight
The KP constant (default 25)

member.name: M:Iot.Device.GoPiGo3.GoPiGo.SetMotorPositionKD(Iot.Device.GoPiGo3.Models.MotorPort,System.Byte)
member.summary: Set the motor target position KD constant If you set KP higher, the motor will be more responsive to errors in position, at the cost of perhaps overshooting and oscillating. KD slows down the motor as it approaches the target, and helps to prevent overshoot. In general, if you increase kp, you should also increase KD to keep the motor from overshooting and oscillating. See as well https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PID_controller
member.param: The Motor port to use, can be MotorLeft and/or MotorRight
The KD constant (default 70)

member.name: T:Iot.Device.HardwareMonitor.OpenHardwareMonitorWmi
member.summary: This class connects to a running instance of OpenHardwareMonitor and reads out all available values using WMI. This works only if OpenHardwareMonitor (https://openhardwaremonitor.org/) is currently running. While the tool needs to be run with elevated permissions, the application using this binding does not. The connection using WMI has proven to be unreliable (the WMI classes are sometimes just not visible), therefore OHM versions greater > 0.10.0 use a rest api instead.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.MeasurementConfiguration
member.summary: Measurement configuration. This enum defines the measurement flow of the device, specifically whether or not to incorporate an applied bias to the sensor into the measurement.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.MeasurementConfiguration.Normal
member.summary: Normal measurement configuration (default). In normal measurement configuration the device follows normal measurement flow. The positive and negative pins of the resistive load are left floating and high impedance.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.MeasurementConfiguration.PositiveBiasConfiguration
member.summary: Positive bias configuration for X and Y axes, negative bias configuration for Z axis. In this configuration, a positive current is forced across the resistive load for X and Y axes, a negative current for Z axis.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.MeasurementConfiguration.NegativeBias
member.summary: Negative bias configuration for X and Y axes, positive bias configuration for Z axis. In this configuration, a negative current is forced across the resistive load for X and Y axes, a positive current for Z axis.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.MeasuringMode.Single
member.summary: Single Measuring Mode (Measure only once. In this mode, OutputRate will be invalid.)

member.summary: Number of samples averaged (1 to 8) per measurement output.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.Status.Ready
member.summary: Ready Bit. Set when data is written to all six data registers. Cleared when device initiates a write to the data output registers, when in off mode, and after one or more of the data output registers are written to. When RDY bit is clear it shall remain cleared for a minimum of a 250 μs.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.Status.Lock
member.summary: Data output register lock. This bit is set when some but not all for of the six data output registers have been read. When this bit is set, the six data output registers are locked and any new data will not be placed in these register until one of four conditions are met: all six have been read or the mode changed, a POR is issued, the mode is changed, the measurement is changed.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Hmc5883l.Status.RegulatorEnabled
member.summary: Regulator Enabled Bit. This bit is set when the internal voltage regulator is enabled. This bit is cleared when the internal regulator is disabled.

For ColorSequence.BGR BBBBBGGG GGGRRRRR 43210543 21043210

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219
member.summary:
INA219 Bidirectional Current/Power monitor.
The INA219 is a high-side current shunt and power monitor with an I2C interface. The INA219 monitors both shunt drop and supply voltage, with programmable conversion times and filtering. A programmable calibration value, combined with an internal multiplier, enables direct readouts in amperes. An additional multiplying register calculates power in watts.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.#ctor(System.Device.I2c.I2cDevice)
member.summary: Construct an Ina219 device using an I2cDevice
member.remarks: This binding does not dispose the passed in I2cDevice.
member.param: The I2cDevice initialized to communicate with the INA219.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.#ctor(System.Device.I2c.I2cConnectionSettings)
member.summary: Construct an INA219 device using an I2cConnectionSettings.
member.remarks: This binding creates an I2cDevice ufor communication with the INA219. The I2cDevice is disposed when then INA219 is disposed.
member.param: The I2cConnectionSettings object initialized with the appropriate settings to communicate with the INA219.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.Reset
member.summary: Reset the INA219 to default values;

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.OperatingMode
member.summary: Property representing the Operating mode of the INA219
member.remarks: This allows the user to selects continuous, triggered, or power-down mode of operation along with which of the shunt and bus voltage measurements are made.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.BusVoltageRange
member.summary: Property representing the Bus voltage range of the INA219
member.remarks: This allows the user to selects eiter a 16V range or a 32V range for the ADC reading the bus voltage. In general the lowest range compatible with the application parameters should be selected.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.PgaSensitivity
member.summary: Property representing the voltage range of the Programable Gain Amplifier used in the INA219 to measure Shunt Voltage.
member.remarks: This allows the user to selects a gain for the amplifier reading the shunt voltage before it is applied to the ADC. It can be one of +/-40mV, +/-80mV, +/-160mV or +/-320mV. In general the lowest range compatible with the application parameters should be selected.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.BusAdcResolutionOrSamples
member.summary: Set the Ina219 ADC resolution or samples to be used when reading the Bus voltage.
member.remarks: This can either by the number of bits used for the ADC conversion (9-12 bits) or the number of samples at 12 bits to be averaged for the result.

member.name: P:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.ShuntAdcResolutionOrSamples
member.summary: Set the INA219 ADC resolution or samples to be used when reading the Shunt voltage.
member.remarks: This can either by the number of bits used for the ADC conversion (9-12 bits) or the number of samples at 12 bits to be averaged for the result.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.SetCalibration(System.UInt16,System.Single)
member.summary: Set the INA219 calibration value used to scale the Shunt voltage into a Current reading.
member.remarks: This method allows the user to manually specify the value written to the INA219 calibration register which determines how the shunt voltage reading is scaled into the current register by the INA219. To allow finer control of the scaling the current register does not contain the actual current value and the currentLsb is used to specify how much current in Amperes is represented by the least significant bit of the current register. This will allow the ReadCurrent method to return the corrent current value and by implication ReadPower to return the correct power value as it is derived froom the current value.
member.param: The number of Amperes represented by the LSB of the INA219 current register.
The current value in Amperes of the least significan bit of the calibration register. Defaults to unity so that the register can be read directly.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.ReadCurrent
member.summary: Read the calculated current through the INA219.
member.remarks: This value is determined by an internal calculation using the calibration register and the read shunt voltage and then scaled.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Ina219.ReadPower
member.summary: Get the calculated power in the circuit being monitored by the INA219.
member.remarks: This value is determined by an internal calculation using the calulated current and the read bus voltage and then scaled.

member.summary: Reads a value from the device using pseudo-differential inputs

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Mcp33xx.ReadDifferential(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a 13 bit signed value from the device using differential inputs
member.remarks: The value that is read respresents the difference between the voltage on the value channel and the voltage on the reference channel (valueChannel Reading - referenceChannel Reading). If the valueChannel and the referenceChannel are part of the same channel pairing then the ADC converter will internally subtract the two values. If not then the subtraction is performed in software which may mean that errors are introduced with rapidly changing signals.
member.param: Channel which represents the signal driving the value in a positive direction (valid values: 0 to channelcount - 1).
Channel which represents the signal driving the value in a negative direction (valid values: 0 to channelcount - 1).
member.returns: A 13 bit signed value corresponding to relative voltage level on specified device channels

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Mcp3xxx.ReadPseudoDifferential(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a value from the device using pseudo-differential inputs
member.remarks: Like a normal differential input the value that is read respresents the difference between the voltage on the value channel and the voltage on the reference channel (valueChannel Reading - referenceChannel Reading). However the reference signal in a pseudo-differential input is expected to be connected to the signal ground. This is used to reduce the effect of external electrical noise on the on the inputs. If there is noise where the noise is likey to impact both the value input and the reference input and the action of subtracting the values helps to cancel it out.
member.param: Channel which represents the signal (valid values: 0 to channelcount - 1).
Channel which represents the signal ground (valid values: 0 to channelcount - 1).
member.returns: A value corresponding to relative voltage level on specified device channels

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Adc.Mcp3xxx.ReadDifferential(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a value from the device using differential inputs
member.remarks: The value that is read respresents the difference between the voltage on the value channel and the voltage on the reference channel (valueChannel Reading - referenceChannel Reading). This subtraction is performed in software which may mean that errors are introduced with rapidly changing signals.
member.param: Channel which represents the signal driving the value in a positive direction (valid values: 0 to channelcount - 1).
Channel which represents the signal driving the value in a negative direction (valid values: 0 to channelcount - 1).
member.returns: A value corresponding to relative voltage level on specified device channels

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.BankStyle
member.summary: The MCP28XXX family has an address mapping concept for accessing registers. This provides a way to easily address registers by group or type. This is only relevant for 16-bit devices where it has two banks (Port A and B) of 8-bit GPIO pins.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.BankStyle.Sequential
member.summary: This mode is used specifically for 16-bit devices where it treats the two 8-bit banks as one 16-bit bank.
member.remarks:
Each of the registers are interleaved so that sending two bytes in a row will set the equivalent register for the second bank. This way you can set all 16 GPIO pins/settings with one command sequence.
Note that this behavior is also dependent on the default behavior of IOCON.SEQOP = 0 (the default) which automatically increments the register address as bytes come in.
This is IOCON.BANK = 0 and is the default.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.BankStyle.Separated
member.summary: This mode keeps the two 8-bit banks registers separate.
member.remarks:
While this keeps the register addresses for bank A the same as the 8-bit controllers it requires sending a separate command sequence to set all 16-bits as the second bank's register addresses are not sequential.
Changing IOCON.SEQOP to 1 (not the default) will cause the register address pointer to toggle between Port A and B for the given register if in this mode.
This is IOCON.BANK = 1.

member.summary: A general purpose parallel I/O expansion for I2C or SPI applications.
member.param: The bus the device is connected to.
The output pin number that is connected to the hardware reset.
The input pin number that is connected to the interrupt for Port A (INTA).
The input pin number that is connected to the interrupt for Port B (INTB).
The controller for the reset and interrupt pins. If not specified, the default controller will be used.

The current bank style of the ports. This does not set the bank style- it tells us what the bank style is. It is *highly* recommended not to change the bank style from the default as there is no direct way to detect what style the chip is in and most apps will fail if the chip is not set to defaults. This setting has no impact on 8-bit expanders.
True to dispose the Gpio Controller

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Mcp23x1x.ReadInterrupt(Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Port)
member.summary: Reads the interrupt pin for the given port if configured.

member.name: T:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Port
member.summary: The I/O port used with registers.
member.remarks: 16-bit controllers are logically separated into two 8-bit ports. 8-bit controllers only have one "port" of GPIO pins so this concept is irrelevant in that case.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Port.PortA
member.summary: The first set of 8 GPIO pins.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Port.PortB
member.summary: The second set of 8 GPIO pins.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.IODIR
member.summary: Controls the direction of the data I/O. When a bit is set, the corresponding pin becomes an input. When a bit is clear, the corresponding pin becomes an output.
member.remarks: On reset/power on all bits are set (all pins are input).

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.IPOL
member.summary: Configures the polarity on the corresponding GPIO port bits. When a bit is set, the corresponding GPIO register bit will reflect the inverted value on the pin.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.GPINTEN
member.summary: Controls the interrupt-on-change feature for each pin. When a bit is set, the corresponding pin is enabled for interrupt-on-change. The DEFVAL and INTCON registers must also be configured if any pins are enabled for interrupt-on-change.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.DEFVAL
member.summary: Configures the default comparison value. If enabled (via GPINTEN and INTCON) to compare against the DEFVAL register, an opposite value on the associated pin will cause an interrupt to occur.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.INTCON
member.summary: Controls how the associated pin value is compared for the interrupt-on-change feature. When a bit is set, the corresponding I/O pin is compared against the associated bit in the DEFVAL register. When a bit value is clear, the corresponding I/O pin is compared against the previous value.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.IOCON
member.summary: Contains several bits for configuring the device. See respective datasheet for more details.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.GPPU
member.summary: Controls the pull-up resistors for the port pins. When a bit is set and the corresponding pin is configured as an input, the corresponding port pin is internally pulled up with a 100 kΩ resistor.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.INTF
member.summary: Reflects the interrupt condition on the port pins of any pin that is enabled for interrupts via the GPINTEN register. A 'set' bit indicates that the associated pin caused the interrupt. This register is read-only. Writes to this register will be ignored.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.INTCAP
member.summary: The INTCAP register captures the GPIO port value at the time the interrupt occurred. The register is read-only and is updated only when an interrupt occurs. The register will remain unchanged until the interrupt is cleared via a read of INTCAP or GPIO.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.GPIO
member.summary: Reflects the value on the port. Reading from this register reads the port. Writing to this register modifies the Output Latch (OLAT) register.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp23xxx.Register.OLAT
member.summary: Provides access to the output latches. A read from this register results in a read of the OLAT and not the port itself. A write to this register modifies the output latches that modify the pins configured as outputs.
member.remarks: On reset/power on all bits are not set (all pins are low).

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.Write
member.summary: Writes data to the register beginning at the selected address.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.Read
member.summary: Reads data from the register beginning at the selected address.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.BitModify
member.summary: Allows the user to set or clear individual bits in a particular register.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.LoadTxBuffer
member.summary: When loading a transmit buffer, reduces the overhead of a normal WRITE command by placing the Address Pointer at one of six locations, as indicated by the 3 lower bits.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.RequestToSend
member.summary: Instructs the controller to begin the message transmission sequence for any of the transmit buffers. Buffers are indicated by the 3 lower bits.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.ReadRxBuffer
member.summary: When reading a receive buffer, reduces the overhead of a normal READ command by placing the Address Pointer at one of four locations, as indicated by the lower 2nd and 3rd bits.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.ReadStatus
member.summary: Quick polling command that reads several Status bits for transmit and receive functions.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.RxStatus
member.summary: Quick polling command that indicates a filter match and message type (standard, extended and/or remote) of the received message.

member.name: F:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.InstructionFormat.Reset
member.summary: Resets the internal registers to the default state, sets Configuration mode.

SAM: Sample Point Configuration bit. True = Bus line is sampled three times at the sample point. False = Bus line is sampled once at the sample point.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.Register.BitTimeConfiguration.Cnf3.#ctor(System.Byte,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Cnf3 class.
member.param: PHSEG2[2:0]: PS2 Length bits. (PHSEG2[2:0] + 1) x TQ. Minimum valid setting for PS2 is 2 TQ.
WAKFIL: Wake-up Filter bit. True = Wake-up filter is enabled. False = Wake-up filter is disabled.

SOF: Start-of-Frame Signal bit. If CLKEN(CANCTRL[2]) = 1: True = CLKOUT pin is enabled for SOF signal. False = CLKOUT pin is enabled for clock out function; If CLKEN(CANCTRL[2]) = 0: Bit is don’t care.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CanCtrl class.
member.param: CLKPRE[1:0]: CLKOUT Pin Prescaler bits.
CLKEN: CLKOUT Pin Enable bit. True = CLKOUT pin is enabled. False = CLKOUT pin is disabled(pin is in a high-impedance state).
OSM: One-Shot Mode bit. True = Enabled: Message will only attempt to transmit one time. False = Disabled: Messages will reattempt transmission if required.
ABAT: Abort All Pending Transmissions bit. True = Requests abort of all pending transmit buffers. False = Terminates request to abort all transmissions.
REQOP[2:0]: Request Operation mode bits.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.Register.ErrorDetection.Eflg.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Eflg class.
member.param: EWARN: Error Warning Flag bit. Sets when TEC or REC is equal to or greater than 96 (TXWAR or RXWAR = 1). Resets when both REC and TEC are less than 96.
RXWAR: Receive Error Warning Flag bit. Sets when REC is equal to or greater than 96. Resets when REC is less than 96.
TXWAR: Transmit Error Warning Flag bit. Sets when TEC is equal to or greater than 96. Resets when TEC is less than 96.
RXEP: Receive Error-Passive Flag bit. Sets when REC is equal to or greater than 128. Resets when REC is less than 128.
TXEP: Transmit Error-Passive Flag bit. Sets when TEC is equal to or greater than 128. Resets when TEC is less than 128.
TXBO: Bus-Off Error Flag bit. Bit sets when TEC reaches 255. Resets after a successful bus recovery sequence.
RX0OVR: Receive Buffer 0 Overflow Flag bit. Sets when a valid message is received for RXB0 and the RX0IF bit in the CANINTF register is ‘1’. Must be reset by MCU.
RX1OVR: Receive Buffer 1 Overflow Flag bit. Sets when a valid message is received for RXB1 and the RX1IF bit in the CANINTF register is ‘1’. Must be reset by MCU.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.Register.ErrorDetection.Eflg.#ctor(System.Byte)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Eflg class.
member.param: The value that represents the register contents.

member.summary: TXWAR: Transmit Error Warning Flag bit. Sets when TEC is equal to or greater than 96. Resets when TEC is less than 96.

member.name: M:Iot.Device.Mcp25xxx.Register.Interrupt.CanIntE.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CanIntE class.
member.param: RX0IE: Receive Buffer 0 Full Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt when message is received in RXB0. False = Disabled.
RX1IE: Receive Buffer 1 Full Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt when message is received in RXB1. False = Disabled.
TX0IE: Transmit Buffer 0 Empty Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt on TXB0 becoming empty. False = Disabled.
TX1IE: Transmit Buffer 1 Empty Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt on TXB1 becoming empty. False = Disabled.
TX2IE: Transmit Buffer 2 Empty Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt on TXB2 becoming empty. False = Disabled.
ERRIE: Error Interrupt Enable bit (multiple sources in the EFLG register). True = Interrupt on EFLG error condition change. False = Disabled.
WAKIE: Wake-up Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt on CAN bus activity. False = Disabled.
MERRE: Message Error Interrupt Enable bit. True = Interrupt on error during message reception or transmission. False = Disabled.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the BfpCtrl class.
member.param: B0BFM: Rx0BF Pin Operation mode bit. True = Pin is used as an interrupt when a valid message is loaded into RXB0. False = Digital Output mode.
B1BFM: Rx1BF Pin Operation mode bit. True = Pin is used as an interrupt when a valid message is loaded into RXB1. False = Digital Output mode.
B0BFE: Rx0BF Pin Function Enable bit. True = Pin function is enabled, operation mode is determined by the B0BFM bit. False = Pin function is disabled, pin goes to the high-impedance state.
B1BFE: Rx1BF Pin Function Enable bit. True = Pin function is enabled, operation mode is determined by the B1BFM bit. False = Pin function is disabled, pin goes to the high-impedance state.
B0BFS: Rx0BF Pin State bit (Digital Output mode only). Reads as '0' when Rx0BF is configured as an interrupt pin.
B1BFS: Rx1BF Pin State bit (Digital Output mode only). Reads as '0' when Rx1BF is configured as an interrupt pin.
